notesStmt.note: [NOTES: a notebook containing an alphabetical word-list. In the letter of 18/01/1967, Kenneth MacDonald writes: “Many thanks for your alphabetical list of words with notes. I take it these have been culled both from written sources and dialect usage. They are a valuable reminder of things to be on the alert for, both in reading and in field work.”]

entry.def: cliff, steep rocky slope (burn at foot).
a mountain stream (from preceding [i.e. alt, allt], with meaning transferred).
request; d’aitheasg aon-fhir – as of one accord.
training, guidance; each-aice – a led horse.
exaggeration; excess praise, leading to ‘evil eye’ (old belief).
ploughman; the man who actually did the work. Treabhaiche – the homesteader, or farmer, whether he himself, or servant, did the actual work.
an imis = air ti [?] – about to.
a spinster (actually, not an unmarried female).
wallowing, tumbling, rolling, as horse, calf, etc.; faonagraich (Lewis), ionnfairt (Irish).
cruel, severe, as weather; “geur” with prefix?
a panache or aptitute; bha alt aige ris a’ phìob (N.E.)
passage in prose or poetry; corr-alt – an occasional passage.
skilled hand-work; Old Gael. airecc, airice.
valuable hand-made articles (hence wedding-presents, etc.) (N.E. Inverness).
reproach, disgrace – is aithis domhs’ i.
a dwelling; dùn-àros – a mansion house. Welsh – aros = staying, waiting.
a vassal, one of a subject race, hence fathach – a giant (mistranslation from old Tales).
permission; comhairc (v) – to ask; iomchomharc – salutaion, compliments; dithchomharc – minus permission.
implements of weaving, related to ‘acuinn, acfhuinn’.
mercenary soldier, often of subject tribes, hence idea of “savage”.
period of service, or engagement, (as soldier, etc.).
immovable property, houses, etc.; from sguch (v) move.
some; arail den mhuinntir; arail eile – moreover.

aspiration, lenition of consonants, also séimheachadh; ? but there seems to have been a difference (at times). Mo cheann – analachadh air “c” also d, t, b, p, m, s. Mo làmh – séimheachadh air “l” also n (and f?).
anything added on, appendix, codicil, etc.
a ball (N.E. and Perthshire); pulla, pullag (Arran and S.W. gen.).
come near, go near; baol ri, beul ri – close to, near to; baolam, beulam – nearness; O.G. i bfail = near to?
big belly, as cow (N.E.); peilc (Arran, S.W. gen.), peilicean (Uist). ? seemed in Perths to be a variant of builg, gen. of bolg – a bag, etc.
talking; bu toigh leam brìd riut.
danger; bearn baoghail – forefront of battle.
snipe. Mis-spelt “bog” in some dictionaries as there was no pre-asp. of “c” (chc) in E. and S.W.
water-ouzel. Mis-spelt “bog” in some dictionaries as there was no pre-asp. of “c” (chc) in E. and S.W.
heap; brìg bhuntàta – potato pit above ground. Pollag-bhuntàta – tattie-pit, dug out, partly underground.
tattie-pit, dug out, partly underground. [Cf. brìg]
? lach – place of, as garbhlach, cunglach, etc. hence “breunlach” – rotting place.
a guilty (or ? accused) person; O.G. bidba.
a sudden start; M.G. biodhg, O.G. bédcc. Hence bìogail, bìoganta – lively; bìogair – lively person.
a man’s collar, also muince, also bonna.
van (grocer, etc.); said to be from bùth-gluasad.
front ones (of anything). Cùlanaich – back ones.
(lit. bearing) opportunity; chan eil breith agam air.
joiners rule (S.W.). As always in extreme S.W. and E. “c” not “chc”.
to urge on (as with a stick).
stock of cows, etc.; also race, family.
a kitchen dresser (N.E. Ins., E. Ross, etc.).
a pannier (saddle with hamper basket on each side).

language, particularly spoken, as opposed to written; beurla Shasuinn – language of Saxon; beurla Ghàidheal – Gaelic; Beurla bhàn – gospel (old usage – any word meaning “white” bàn, fionn, ean, geal used in idiom with meaning “holy”). Beurla – English language, is modern and incorrect. Bioball Beurla is absurd (for Bìoball Sasunnach) – bìoball = leabhar; beurla = cainnt; = Leabhar-Cànain = Foclar. Dòighbheurla na Gàidhlige – idiom of G. Mall-bheurlach – slow of speech.
spongy with holes; aran còsach – spongy bread.
a car, a cart, also carn (N.E.).
to plant potatoes with dibble; ciobladh (vn).
shrink, also withdraw; Tha Gàidhlig a’ sìor-chrapadh.
chimney-stack, pillar (E. and S.W.); “o” short acute, not “ow”.
a man’s back (Strathglass, Glenmoriston, etc.); chiurr mi mo chrotach.
pigtail of hair; ? ciabh – dial. ci-u; ? Eng. queue.
flesh food, for winter, salted, smoked, etc.
tuft of hair, grass, etc.; ceasg lìn (flax); ceasg clòimhe (wool); hence ceasganna – baskets, made of such; applied to ‘mermaid’ because of her long hair.
lock of hair, bunch; ceadan clòimhe.
(Brendan’s candles) phosphorescence. Corrupted caille-bèanain (Perth, Arg.), coille-bianain (N. by W.).
a hand’s turn; cha dean esan cama-corraig.
but and ben; cearn – kitchen; cùlais – back place.
as (m), ais (f) two of many suffixes meaning “place of”.
a crease; cramaisg (v); cramasgadh. (Ins., Ross, Skye, etc.)
a hill pony (Strathspey, Aird, etc.). ? Eng. “filly”.
a hollow; cabhan – small hollow; Glas chabh – Glasgow, the Green Hollow?
confusion; one of many words from “measg” (N. Ins.).
a meadow, damp by river, loch, or sea edge (N.E. and Perths.).
road, way: Glengarry – An Cà’ Ruadh, Black Isle – Craigiehow = Creag a’ Chodha.
covenant, bargain, agreement; “o” not “ow” nn pronounced.
of tapered point; hence steep, as pointed hill; hence quick to wrath.
quickness to wrath; Bible corruich – wrath.
short “o”; obligation, death-bed entreaty, etc. (N.E.). ? From “cur, cuir, cor” – nì a chuirear air duine, agus fheumas bhith dèanta aige.

(1) stipulation, obligation; tha mi ga chur còrachd ort (N.W.). ? From “còir” – ni as còir a bhith deanta, is nach gabh a sheachnadh. ? From “connar, connradh” above with “nn” dropping out before “r” as happens in N.W. only. (2) disguising accent, etc.; chuir e còrachd air a theanga (Argyll). ? còirich, còraich, còrachadh – arrange, organise. Also càraich, càradh – arrange, hence sort (as letters), hence repair (as boats, fences, etc.).
a wooden tub, or similar container. Also gothan (m), goithin (m).
a wooden tub, or pail (N.E.). It is possible that the name Clach na Cùdainn was originally Clach na gcudan or Clach nan cudan, with lengthening of “u” by Anglicisation, vide Bàrra for Barra.
a stirk; sometimes transl. “heifer”; but colpach fireann.
calm, settled; also applied to “setting” of cement.
to adjust, settle by law; coigeirt (vn).
a border, a fringe, a selvage.
catrach math gaoithe – strong wind (Arran, Bute, Cowal, Kintyre).
anything of wooden boards, as partition, or floor, or house.
out-run; cathair a’ chùl-chinn – watch-knoll of out-run.
any small coin, of little value; chan fhiach e cianag. Welsh – ceiniog = a penny.
due; b’e sin a bu dìr dhomhsa.
a heap, a small mound; dùcan dubh-threabha – mole-hill.
pottering, doing little by little also a’ driongan – pottering slowly, doing a little.
an example, a curiosity, a quotation.

hesitating (Ross-s.); tomhartaich (W. Breadalbane); teabardaich (Uist). The first two seem to be the same word, e.g. E. Ross damacraich; Strathglass damarcaich; Strathspey domarcaich; Brae Mar and Atholl domartaich; E. Brd Alb. tomartaich or tomhartaich; W. Brd Alb. tomhartaich; usually ag damacraich, ’san tomhartaich, ’san teabardaich.
expectation; dòich – likely, dòcha – more likely.
air-tremble near ground on hot day (Strathglass); also “spinning top”. Crith-dhìobairtean (Mull).
scatter, dissolve (Arg.); dol gu draibh – go to ruin (N.W.).
sturdy person, adj. daganta, daigeil, dailceanta, stalcanta.
an acorn; from darach or from darc, dorc, durc, a cone.
a fir-cone; in N. Ins. usually dim. “durcan, duircean”.
shoot; feadh diùrachaidh – (within) range, shooting distance.
a poor wretch, a person of no account.
end, rear; deò-là – evening; gu deò (till the end) – for ever; fa-dheòi, mu dheòi – at last, ultimately.
a row or drill or furrow.
demand; solar is éileamh – supply and demand.
pain in hands from cold; also eanglach, ionglach; péileadh (Perthshire).
last furrow of each bout, division of ploughing, lower than the rest as the plough turns the earth outward on both sides.
particular, certain; an ionad earalta – in a particular place.
wet grassy flat, by side of river, loch, sea.
steep part between two shelves of land, old beach, etc. (Ins., Ross-s.)
(1) woods; (2) weapons of wood, arrows, spears, etc. (3) the warrior who used them.
lower part of slope; hence a bhàn (= i bhfàn) down (N.E.).
widow (exact cognate); hence faobh above: the widows of the slain being the booty of the victors (old Tales).
stop, stay, dwell; fosadh – dwelling; also fasadh in place-names. Also sos, sosadh, same meaning and usage.
one who has been proclaimed an outlaw.
cause, reason, material from which something is made; hence braird of corn, etc.
a’ fur = equipping, preparing (as regiment). (root of “foireann”?)
wild animals (deer, etc.); hence fiadh – a deer (from adj?).
possible, practicable; adj. from “feud faod”? Is feudarra gun dean mi e – perhaps I’ll do it.
a pod (pea, bean, etc.); also spàlag.
a ferrule; connected with “idh” a chain link?
out of order, out of circulation, unobtainable, etc. (E. Inverness).

a fugitive, from one clan, who got sanctuary and livelihood (cattle, etc.) in territory of another clan. Unlike the saor-chlanna, who had rights that even the chief could not over-rule, he had no rights (daor-chlanna). Mac an fhuidhir (Macnair, Weir, etc.) sometimes made into Mac Iain Uidhir for reasons of snobbery.

= Gàidhealach = Gaelic (adj); hence Gàidhealtachd – state of being Gàidhealta also Gàidhealachas – state of being Gàidhealach. Gallta, Éireannta, Sasunnta = Gallach, Éireannach, Sasunnach but ‘ach’ preferred to ‘ta’ in words of this kind, usually.

said by some to mean “pertaining to Caithness”. This is wrong. Applied by Gaelic people in Sutherland and W. Caithness to non-Gaelic people in N.E. Caithness, but not to them only, to non-Gaelic people anywhere.

said by some to be Gaelic name for modern Caithness. This is not correct. Gaelic was spoken in S. and W. part of modern Caithness, and Gallabh was never used for any Gaelic speaking district. Gallabh = N.E. part of Caithness, Suth. and W. Caithness, but not it only. E. Ins. usage: Gallabh = Laigh o’ Moray. Perths. usage: Gallabh = Lower Angus, Mearns, etc. Gallabh, Gallaibh, Gallu = any non-Gaelic district or place especially on East Coast, north of the main Galltachd.
inlet of sea, marsh by sea.
certain sound in ear (omen of calamity, old belief) (N.E.).
(1) gossip (Perthshire); gabhannach. (2) a particular herd (fold) of cattle, etc.; gabhann gearr-adharcaich aig Morair Sìm.
drooping of head to one side.
a party, a group, etc. (N.E.); grunn (Arg.).
vice, clamp (smith, joiner, etc.); also glamaradh.
a large vehicle of any kind (such as big bus, or cattle-float, etc.).
a hole, cave, or cavern (E. Ross).
gluc na sùla – socket of eye.
a silly, foolish trick or action.
silly talk, blethering (N. Ins.); glaigeal (Barra); glagair (m) – non-stop talker (Ins., Ross.).
a container, or measure, as of whiskey.
table-fork; sgian is gobhlag; more common as “hay-fork”, etc.
short-sighted; confused with gearr-adharcach – short-horned (cattle), hence gearr-dhearcach and various other terms.
pertaining to Islands, West and East Indies.
a hyphen; also buabhann; also fleisgin.
survivor; but confused with iarach, siarach (western); hence iarmarach – survivor.
pain in fingers from cold (N.E.); Lewis: é alaich; Uist: è alaich (spelt from sound); péileadh (Perths.).
a lantern; also buait, crùisean, lòichead, lòchran, etc.
skin lid, or covering, on cask; iolaman, iolman (Sutherland).
remote corners, backward places; hence iargalta – rough, uncouth, etc.
fight, battle; (lit. skilled action, see aireag).
controversy; (but see ciap v. – harass, quarrel with, etc. = ag iapail?).
an overful, or crowded, closet, hut, apartment.
to cram together, to huddle, etc.
a payer, a rent-payer, a tenant.
above, over; os [sic] an tiùrr – above high-tide mark.

Orkney and Shetland Islands (since 13th century); not a fixed place-name, but a descriptive term, the extent of which varied as the power of the Norse waxed or waned. At height of Norse power, Innse-Gall = all islands from Shetlands to the Isle of Man; after Somhairle Mac Giolla Bride’s first victory Innse Gall = islands north of Ardnamurchan; after Somhairle’s 2nd victory Innse Gall = Orkneys and Shetlands only. NE Highl. C. S. – Innse Gall but more commonly Innsean Gallach, Eileana [?] Gallach = Orkney, Shetland. Innse Gaidheal(ach) – Western Isles (Lewis to Islay) + Arran, Bute. Innse-Gall not applied to any Gaelic-speaking islands. Bardic usage: Innse Gall = Western Isles (Lewis to Islay) regardless of fact that they had ceased to be Innse-Gall in 13th century and had become Gaelic. As long as the Bards had comharda, uaithne, uaim, and the other obair-ghréis of their trade, they didn’t bother about truth. Modern literary, artificial – imitation of Bardic usage, above. Incorrect.
mud; mud flat covered by high tide, or floods.
also fixed groups of notes and grace-notes, peculiar to pibroch music, hence taor-lùdh, crun-lùdh, leum-lùdh, etc.
quacking of ducks; lachraich na lacha luin.
blade of oar; wooden spoon, spade, etc. or anything similar.
cutting off; air leòdh – cut off; leòd (= leo’ta?) – N. Ins. maimed.
sheen of flames; from “lìomh” = li-w = liu.
edge of deep water, round loch side (Perths. N.E.).
compar. of iol ‘numerous’; cha liu ná – not more numerous than.
skimmed milk; bainne lom (“o” acute, short, not ow; Strathspey, Perth, etc.).
shining; lòchradh le fallas – shining with sweat (N.E.).
red-hot; white hot; lit. shining hot.
a spade; same word as “ràmh” – oar; Welsh rhaw – a spade.
harm hurt; same word as leòn ‘wound’.
coastal flat; sa mhoroich (dative case); mur + magh or faich.
infant; maothar na treuda – young of the flock.
remains; mainearach gàraidh – remains of a wall.
pertaining to sea; gen. ‘na mara’ more commonly used.
sub-tenant of tuath (tenants of uachdaran N. Ins.).
affected tilt of cap, toss of head, etc.
gap in teeth, mistranslated “lisp” which was just a side-effect of above.
a bag, a boll, a measure (S.W.). (mioch – bushel of oats, etc. Ir. [?])
kind of cover; from mullach – top.
bundle, group, etc.; muirear a céibhe, muirear a fholt (fhuilt) – mass of hair.
the little, or smallest of anything.
hazy, dim, as weather, light, etc.
mishap, misadventure. (Mid. G. cineamhuinn – fate, etc.)
whiskey distilled from oats, or anything other than barley.
large lump or mass as of rocks. (from bulg ‘to bulge’ with eclipsis?)
lump or blister (N. Ins., E. Ross, W. Ross). [Cf. mulc.]
nearer, nearest; bu neasa dhuinn; nà ri / nàr ri (could never make out whether ‘na’ or ‘nar’ with ‘ri’ always after it) = near, beside (Perths.).
noise, shout; nuallghair – loud shout; nuallghul – loud weeping.
hoodie crow (also vulgar, neabh, neobh = member [?], hence “a wee nyaff”).
big, great (tall, etc.); òigfhear oll; oll-ghuthach – loud voiced; compar. oille. (“o” acute short, not “ow”, E. and S. always before ll, nn)
old name for deer; fiadh means just “wild”, abbrev. of fiadhmhìol.
over, above; os uile – above all; os mo chionn – over my head.
occasion; air an ocaid sin. (from Eng.?)
a bus; turus-omuis, reug-omuis – bus journey (N.E.).
a dibble; also plèag, pleadhag; also stibhin, stifin.
a cloak, a (sheepskin or leather) coat.
spike, long-toothed harrows, etc; hence procach – 1 year stag (Sutherland).
softer place in marsh (Argyll), priach (Lewis, Skye).

the playing of pipes; the profession, or performance of the piper. Not used in sense “Ceòl Mór” by native speakers. That usage, in Eng. only, originated among Eng. speaking collectors of pipe music. Urlar – the theme, or ground. Leagadh – variation – Anglo-Irish “a falling”. Lùdh (lùth, lùgh) – fixed group of notes and grace-notes peculiar to pibroch. Caslùdh – grip (piper’s jargon). Bàrludh, barr-lùdh. Leumlùdh. Taorludh [sic]. Crùnlùdh. Siubhal or iùl-lùdh, etc.
motor-cycle (N. Ins.); said to be an abbrev. of rothar-motar.
fit, as of sickness, madness, laughter.
dust of meal, fine earth, or similar.
a mob, party of soldiers, etc.
flush (red); ruamna na feirge – flush of wrath; also ruamhna, ruaimleach.
robust, having colour of health (as old person).
anything thick, of its kind; rot maide.
ragnails, ragged skin at base of finger-nails (N.E.); rifeineach (Uist); righinneach (Arran, Kintyre, etc.). Slender “ch” commonly reduced to gh.
field out of cultivation, under grass; ràrach – pasture; ràraichean (radharaichean) – places of pasture, but fields, not hill-ground. (E. Ross, N. Ins.)
a bare place (N. Ins.); Bràigh Rùsgaich.
king material, royalty; damhna = fochann = adhbhar (aobhar).
course (as ship), career; luath-réim – quick progress.
reign, lifetime, career (from “réim” above with asp. of m).
unwelcome flattery; ruiceach (adj); ‘c’ not ‘chc’ – E and S as always.
untidy; also ròpach; rèapalas (m), ròpaiche (f), ròip (f).
species of long grass, grows on muddy flats by river, etc.
use, make use of; rèaraich. (from riar, réir?)
= seo. Mid. G. literature, but surviving in Sutherland and E. Ross in sense “here”; not “this”.
huddle, draw in, cram in; OG sceng; Uist sgionc (v) – to squeeze in still more.
writhing, coiling (as serpent); also applied to music.
working in gutters, slush, etc.; any such wet muck.
a scout; Sirich Lòbhatach – Lovat Scouts; Marcaichean Mhic Shimi.
peg for hanging things on; (also) storn.
condition above normal (fire, flood, etc.) (Perths.); tha stearn (steairn) air – tipsy. Also “caoir” – tha caoir air an allt, leis a’ bhruaich – big flood.
sloucher, dawdler; mis-spelt slabhcar; never a “b” in this word.
“skin” as on cold porridge, soup, etc. (N.E); tha sgeir air a theanga.; sgir (Lewis) – chan eil sgir air cnàmhan an eich sen [sic].
dribbling of food on clothes of infant; etc.
untidy person; srìl, srìleag, srilin or srìlean (S.W.).
looking around in a silly way (N.E.); as usual ‘c’ not ‘chc’.
a “match”, a game; spac iomain, spac ghleacaidh, etc. (N.E.)
a snatch; thug an cù sic air.
a ditch of stagnant water (N.E.); ma bhios ruith air an uisge, cha “stang” i.
anything good; son-bìdh (lit. goodness of food); air son – for benefit (of), for sake (of). [Cf. don.]
anything bad; don-dòchas; don-bìdh; air don – to detriment (of). [Cf. son.]
broken branch, or jagged stump left (Black Isle).
a bout, a “doze”, a quantity; sluim galair.
a bout, a “doze”, a quantity; slaim cratain; perhaps slam for snowflake is a misunderstanding and means a “quantity” of snow.
drive cattle, etc. (N.E.); drive a car; O.G. sétugad carpait.
sgaoil air, sgaoil fo (v) – let loose on, shoot; beul sgaoileach – one unable to keep a secret.
an upright, a pillar, a standard.
air sogh – for joy; fa shogh – at ease, in comfort.
hay, corn built up in barn.

a shilling; but sgilin Albannach = peighinn Breatannach (is Sasunnach); tastan Albannach = sgilin Sasunnach (is Breatannach); but “shilling” is the meaning of the word sgilin at all times; when applied to British “penny”, it does not mean “penny” but “Scots shilling”.
border, edge, limit; cuir teòra ri – to limit.
mark out as for building. (same as preceding words? [i.e. teòr, teòrainn])
chase (as hounds); swift play of fingers (as piper); a’ tafann air – urging on.
second of anything; meur tànaiste or tàiniste.
cur tilgin – put ground to potatoes.
avoiding, shunning; theab mi tuiteam = I avoided falling = I nearly fell.
bush, head of cabbage, etc.; tor aitinn; also tom, tom aitinn.
quiet, tranquil as sea; bright, splendid.
sudden eruption, earthquake; tul prefix – sudden, confused with tur ‘complete’: tul-bhreug – sudden quick lie; tur-bhreug – complete lie.
prefix “continual”; ta-ghairm – ever-calling; ta-mhaoidheamh – ever-threatening; ta-ghul – ever-weeping.
business, affair, occasion, etc.; tosgan deifir – urgent affairs.
connecting strap, chain, etc.; sporran strap.
trollaidh cnatain (Strathglass). (treall – short period of time?)
bout of coughing (Lewis). (treall – short period of time?)
bout of sickness. (treall – short period of time?)
bout of sickness (MacEachen). (treall – short period of time?)
cupboard (Perths.); “t” of article? an t-airleas, etc?
teirbeirt (vn); send off; let slip (as hounds).
face, head; tul ri tul – face to face.
an tuab, an t-uab – cattle disease, about the mouth (spelled by sound only).
cast, shoot as arrow, etc.; also ‘transfer’.
pitter patter (as of sheeps’ trotters on road).
ornamented mantle worn by Chief Bard or Poet.

striped cloth, with pattern the same, longwise and crosswise (warp and weft), modern; but not necessarily so of old. Mid Gaelic tuartan – striped or coloured cloth. The term “breacan” includes tartan, but also checked, striped, or coloured cloth which is not “tartan” in modern sense.

very; gara fuar, gara fliuch (Kintyre, also Lewis); actually just garbh = rough. Usage taken over into Eng. in Kintyre as “wild and cold” = very cold, “wild and wet” = very wet, but spreading to things, where its primary meaning was hardly suitable.
landslide; or torrent of rain causing it (Reay, Sutherland).
cave; uaigh (f) – grave; confusion between these, possibly same word originally; Welsh “ogof” cave = uaghamh?
Highlands; the word Gàidhealtachd does not mean “Highlands”, but coincided, by accident of circumstances, about Culloden period.
Cha ruigear leas a bhith an urra ris, do thaobh àit-ainmean. Uaireannta chan eil aige ach e féin ag cur Gàidhlig air an rian Shasunnach den ainm. Theagamh gu bheil cuid diubh seo ceart gu leóir.

Carn an Eòin, Sgorr Hurlaidh, Bealach na h-Airde, Bealach na Gaoithe, Cnoc Ormadail, Traigh Chill Orain, Cnoc Mhic ’Ille Mhinniche, Port an Òbain, na Dùintean, Bealach an Leóghainn, Port na Cuilc, Carraig a’ Chait, Meall na Suiridh.

form.orth: Peart, Earra-Gaidheal, suas gu Linne Sheilich

entry.def: Loch Fìne, Inbhir-Aora, Dun Chuaich, Meall Réidh, Tom Breac, Leac nam Ban, Sonnachan, Loch Obha, Loch Éite, Beinn Laoigh, Beinn Dobhrain, Raineach, Loch Triochatan, Lairig-Gartain.
Beinn Dùn Dà Ghaoith, Mainnir nam Fiadh, Beinn Mheadhoin, Péighinn a’ Ghobhainn, Eileanan Glasa, Loch nan Ceall.

Allt Samhairigh, Creag an Fhithich, Achadh Forsa, Clagan, Uladal, Meall Achadh a’ Chuirn, Cnoc Carrach, Achadh Gabhail, Coire nan Gobhar, Loch Suaineairt, Loch a’ Chothruim, Gleann na Tairbeirt, Corran.
Inbhir Allt Coire an Lochain, Drochaid Lòchaidh, Beinn Nibheis, Sgor Choinnich, Meall Lochan nan Dubh Lochan, Allt a’ Ghiùbhais Chruinn, Loch Airceig, Loch Garadh, Gleann Cinngidh.
Sgor Beag, Creag nan Damh, Allt Beithe, Gleann Seile, Achadh nan Gort, Loch Dubhthaich, Loch Luinge, Coille na Tobhtaig, Conchra, Poll an Tairbh, Omhanaich.

Loch an Iasgaich, Loch nam Breac Móra, Gleann Atadail, Loch Carran, Cam Allt, na Cùileagan, Cladh a’ Chlachain, Sròn Deorsa, Loch Ma-Ruibh, Beul Atha na Crà, Loch Dughaill, Tuaidh, Carn Odhar, Achadh nam Seileach, Carn Breac, Frìth Chùlainn, Goirtean Fraoich, Eas an Teampuill, Torran Cuilinn, Loch Cùlainn, Carn Dhomhnuill Mhic a’ Ghobhainn, Ceann Loch Iùbh, Beinn Éighe.

Inbhir Àsdal, Fionn Loch, Lochan Fada, Tealladal, Creag Thollaidh, Turnaig, Uaghaidh, Beinn Àirigh a’ Charr, a’ Mhaighdean, Gruinneard Garbh, Meall na Doire, Sròin Dubh, Bad a’ Chròtha, Port an Sgùmainn.

Trondairnis, Eileanan Sianta, Gearraidh na h-Aibhne, Loch Tungabhat, Mùirnean, Mosgal, Ùig, Eileanan Flannach, Lingarabhaigh, Cliseam, Sròn Scourst, Sròn Ulladal, Tarran Mór, Loch Réasort, Croladha, Crabhadal, Beinn Bhaoghla, Hiort, Cuan Sgìthe.
